interpretation_summary: The replication executed successfully after minor path and gender-coding fixes. Using the Gerhold_covid_Azg9_0948 dataset (German adults), the planned tests were run: (1) mean difference in worry (mh_anxiety_1) and (2) difference in agree-rate (Likert 4–5). Results show women report higher mean worry than men (diff≈0.185 on 1–5 scale, p<0.001, small d≈0.165), consistent with the hypothesized direction. However, the agree-rate difference was essentially zero and non-significant, diverging from the original report where women’s agreement was substantially higher (68.2% vs 55.7%, p<0.01). Overall, the replication provides partial support: directionally consistent on means but not on dichotomized agreement.

fidelity_assessment.method_alignment: High alignment: The executed code implemented the preregistered tests (two-sample t-test on mh_anxiety_1 and two-proportion z-test for agree rates) with the specified data filters (exclude gender==3) and summaries (Ns, means, SDs, Cohen’s d). Outputs were saved and reported as planned.

deviations.issue_description: Data path mismatch (/app/data vs /workspace) required script patching to locate input and write outputs.
deviations.impact: Low: Purely infrastructural; no impact on statistical results.

deviations.issue_description: Female variable coding was numeric floats (1.0/0.0) leading to empty groups on first attempt; script patched to robustly derive female_bin (use numeric female>=0.5; fallback to gender==2).
deviations.impact: Low: Corrected grouping and enabled proper analysis; no change to planned estimands.

deviations.issue_description: Replication dataset not identical to the original study’s sample (Gerhold survey vs original ISO-panel).
deviations.impact: Moderate: Differences in sample/time/instrument may explain divergence on agree-rate significance despite aligned direction on mean differences.

results_comparison.hypothesis_tested: Women will express more concern about COVID-19 than men.
results_comparison.original_results: Percent agreeing worried about COVID-19: 62.1% overall; women 68.2% vs men 55.7% (Δ=12.5 pp), p<0.01. Direction: women > men.
results_comparison.replication_results: Mean difference (mh_anxiety_1, 1–5): +0.1852 (SE=0.0224), 95% CI [0.1412, 0.2291], t=8.2574, p=1.68e-16, Cohen’s d=0.1645 (women > men). Agree-rate difference (4–5): −0.26 pp (SE≈0.00935), 95% CI [−2.09 pp, 1.57 pp], z=−0.276, p=0.783 (n.s.). Exploratory mh_anxiety_3 mean diff: +0.0597, p=0.0079.
results_comparison.overall_answer: Partial: The replication supports the directional hypothesis via a significant mean difference, but fails to replicate the original significant gender gap on the agree-rate metric.

replication_report: Partial replication: Women report higher mean COVID-19 worry (small, significant effect), but the dichotomized agree-rate difference is null, unlike the original 12.5 pp gap (p<0.01).

failure_handling.suggestions: Harden file path handling to search common mount points and expose a configurable input/output path; include unit tests for group construction from gender/female variables.

Document and, if possible, match the original item wording and response options; consider applying survey weights if used in the original; replicate both mean and dichotomized metrics and assess sensitivity to the agree threshold (e.g., 5-only vs 4–5).

Where feasible, obtain the original ISO-panel dataset or a closer matched sample (timing/provider); report demographic balance and timing differences; perform subgroup/sensitivity analyses to probe why agree-rate diverges despite mean difference agreement.

notes: The small but significant mean difference with a null agree-rate suggests thresholding may obscure modest shifts in central tendency; results could be sensitive to the chosen dichotomization cutpoint. The replication dataset is from a different project/time, which may alter base rates of worry and the distribution of responses across Likert categories. Reporting weighted estimates and verifying identical item wording would improve comparability.
